bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Luis Espinosa y G. Caceres, March 31, 1945

div1.p: Hench attempts to explain how he came to misunderstand Espinosa's letter. Espinosa's letter, in Spanish, was not translated correctly. Hench assures him that he will cooperate with him and his work in the Finlay Institute.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Luis Espinosa y G. Caceres, March 31, 1945
div1.opener:
Please return
PSH/cb
31 March, 1945
Dr. Luis Espinosa y G. Caceres
Director de la Division de Relaciones
Medicas Y Sanitarias Panamericanas
Instituto Finlay
Infanta Y Zaldo
La Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Espinosa:
div1.p:
As we say in America, this is surely “one on me”. It is
a good joke indeed that I was led to misunderstand your nice letter of
January 10. I read Spanish very poorly and do not trust my knowledge
at all. I handed your letter to a woman here who had lived several
years in Cuba as a young girl. She gave me a brief word of mouth trans-
lation and led me to believe that I had been asked to be a Director.
This puzzled me, as I noticed definitely that you had signed your name
as the Director; therefore, I sent the letter to a woman at the Mayo
Clinic who translates Spanish. Indeed, she is the Spanish translator
and interpreter and handles much of the personnel work with our South
American patients who come to the Mayo Clinic. She sent me back a
written translation which again stated that I had been appointed a
Director. Indeed, she stated that in two different sentences. I was
still puzzled but decided that probably it was an honorary appointment
and that you were appointing honorary Directors in various countries,
as is done by certain medical groups. Therefore, I wrote you as I did
in my letter of 26 February.

Please rest assured that whether I am a self-appointed
Director or not, I will be very happy indeed to cooperate with you
in any way in your work. In recent years I have visited Cuba almost
every winter, as my wife and I like to take our vacation partly in
Florida and partly in Cuba. I hope to avail myself of the privilege
of meeting you on my next visit and between us, we can drink a toast
to you, as the real Director, and to me, as a self-appointed Director,
now demoted!

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service
